text:
Domain login account owns public_html/cgi-bin. Error.log shows: "(OS 5) access 
denied" only when trying to run a cgi (example: 105gradecheck.exe). Apache 
running as Local Account. Incoming requests for ~userid translated (via 
AliasMatch) to append login domain-name to userid to match file system. Apache 
properly serves other webpages from same account. No responses on the apache-
user list. No FAQ's. No docs describing possible actions to take. The form at 
the above site may be filled with any values to test it.
creator: dforeman@stny.rr.com
presidente@fofao.cjb.net
text: The CGIs works fine in other windows (95,98,ME), but not in XP

creator: dforeman@stny.rr.com
text:
CGI's DO work properly on XP, but NOT when the system is in a domain, and the 
user profile ends with ".domain_name". CGI's are running perfectly on my non-
domain machine.

Hi, Dennis.

This is not solved nor fixed for me... :(

Do you could help me to setup it???

Thanks

[]'s

Fofao


PS: Excuse me for my bad english... :)
creator: presidente@fofao.cjb.net

text: Dennis how do i check to mske sure im not using a domain or falty domain?
creator: lord_shilvet@yahoo.com

text:
Stanley,
You are in a domain if your login panel shows a domain name or if your user 
files (where "My Documents" is located), are under a name like "<id>.<domain-
name>", instead of just "<id>". It isn't clear (to me) from the Apache 
documentation, just where to put files/directories that are qualified by a 
domain name. That is, when someone access MY webspace, which is in a domain 
named WTSN, he uses: dforeman.cs.binghamton.edu/~foreman. This has to be 
translated (by a line in the httpd.conf file) into 
dforeman.cs.binghamton.edu/~foreman.WTSN
My CGI files then have to be accessed through this translation as well.
creator: dforeman@stny.rr.com
jorton@redhat.com
text:
Looks like some system permissions error; marking invalid; please try a user
support forum if you need further help:
 
http://httpd.apache.org/lists.html#http-users

The following "aliasmatch" rule fixed the problem. 
AliasMatch /~([a-zA-Z0-9]*)/?(.*)  "C:/Documents and Settings/$1.WTSN/My
Documents/public_html/$2" 

The $1 contains the incoming owner name (as in "~foreman") and the $2 contains
the rest of the request after being parsed out by the regexp shown.

it would be nice if there was an example of this in the Apache docs.
creator: dforeman@stny.rr.com
